description: From Middle English corrōden, that borrowed from Old French corroder or directly from Latin corrōdere (“to gnaw”), from con- (“completely”) +‎ rōdere (“to gnaw”).

verbs.description: corrode (third-person singular simple present corrodes, present participle corroding, simple past and past participle corroded)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To eat away bit by bit; to wear away or diminish by gradually separating or destroying small particles of, as by action of a strong acid or a caustic alkali.
(transitive) To consume; to wear away; to prey upon; to impair.
examples: My morale is being corroded day by day.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To have corrosive action; to be subject to corrosion.
